Thanks for the review. While going through the code I discovered that we could run into a NPE if the run() method starts to execute and simultaneously the snapshotting starts before the state has been initialized (localSources and localReaders). Even worse, we could end up in a situation where  we only had these initialized these with empty lists, checkpointed them, subsequently failed and would then restore an inconsistent empty state. Running all initialization code in the `open()` method solves these race conditions.

Seems to have pulled in a bunch of extraneous commits. I assume they are actually already from `master`. Instead of merging branch `master`, you should `git rebase origin/master` (or `github/master`, depending on what you named your remote). Then only your commits should show up here.

So I played with this a fair bit and was able to almost get the tests passing. I've attached the diff, which is not quite complete.

A few things to notice
- Generally, we should try to avoid `getReturnType` -- which returns `Class<?>` in favor of `getGenericReturnType` -- which returns a Java `Type`. This will give us the new type information. However, it will indeed require some potentially more invasive changes in the code. 
- While you can compare `Class<?> == Class<?>`, because they're Java primitives, that's probably not appropriate for `Type` objects. Instead we should use `Type.equals(Type)`.
- In general, the classes that extract properties should use the `iface` not the `klass` -- that will preserve the generic types.
- Minor changes to populate the list of already-present functions. Since we're no longer inspecting a class, we can drop the default `equals`, `hashCode`, and `toString`.

Here is what I think is left.
- [ ] we now have much better type info available -- we should leverage this to do better deduplication. E.g., if I have two different interfaces, one of which declares `List<Integer> getList();` and another of which declares `List<Long> getList()` we should be able to detect this now and throw an error.
  
  I think before we did not have this support, but I may be wrong. A unit test should be able to clarify.
- [ ] As Luke pointed out, there are some places we can likely simplify the conversion code because we can give Jackson better type info.
- [ ] In general, would like to see unit tests fleshing out the new type checks we can do. E.g., users could make collections like `Map`s before using Jackson's ability to parse JSON in a single argument. I believe in practice this was only used for `Map<String, String>` or maybe `Map<JSON primitive, JSON primitive>` We should add tests to check that we can do more interesting stuff now.
